events.about: Ceci est un concours de développement mobile

events.name: Adobe WebUp #7
events.about:
Adobe WebUp 7  va fi o editie mai scurta decat cele cu care v-am obisnuit. Motivul? Au venit caldurile, vacanta, perioada concediilor.

Si de aceasta data vom avea partea de socializare/networking. Pentru ca din feedbackul primit a rezultat ca nu toata lumea intelege care este rostul acestei pauze m-am gandit sa va dau cateva motive pentru care ar fi interesanta: discutii mai detaliate cu prezentatorii sau ceilalti participanti despre subiectele serii, discutii intre voi despre orice este cool in web azi, prezentarea de oportunitati/joburi pentru web developeri/designeri.

 La editia trecuta am avut pentru prima data un hackathon. Am incorporat feedbackul primit si am hotarat sa tinem hackathonul separat de eveniment pentru a avea mai mult timp la dispozitie. Ca urmare, daca doriti sa va inscrieti la hackathonul de pe 28 Iulie click aici.

Programul conferintei #7 este:

18:30 – 18:55 Registration   
18:55 – 19:00 Introduction   
19:00 – 19:30

JavasSript Applications Architecture

Am sa vorbesc despre arhitectura aplicatiilor javascript  (thick client, Single Pagec Javascript Intesive etc.)

Structura este urmatoarea: 

  • Structurarea codului in module si `clase` cu require.js
  • Design Patterns: (doar) Pub/Sub si Mediator in JS
  • Separation of concerns, MVC in javascript
  • Inchei cu Backbone.js vs. Ember.js

Despre Alexandru:

Are BS de la Electronica si MSc de Ingineria Sistemelor Internet de la Automatica. Dupa absolvire a lucrat in doua startupuri romanesti (Squeeqly.com, CleverTaxi.com) si numai JavaScript (front-end si node.js). Este co-fondator Vibetrace.com, o companie care produce tooluri social-media pentru magazinele online.

 Alexandru Topliceanu
19:30 – 20:00

Brackets - a new genre of HTML editors

Nu cu multa vreme in urma Adobe a lansat public un proiect open source numit Brackets. Din multe puncte de vedere acest proiect este extraordinar.

In aceasta sesiune vei afla ce este si mai ales care este viitorul acestui proiect.

Mihai Corlan este worldwide developer evangelist la Adobe. Postura din care lucreaza, scrie si prezinta despre tehnologii web si produse Adobe. Mai multe pe blogul lui.

 Mihai Corlan / Adobe
20:00 – 20:30

Networking Break

  

 

Pentru amatorii de Twitter, nu uitati ca tagul editiei 7 este #AdobeWebUp7 si contul oficial de Twitter este @AdobeWebUp. Ca sa citez dintr-un clasic Citeste si da mai departe! - vrem sa avem sala plina de oameni pasionati de web ca si tine :)

Ne vedem pe 26 Iulie incepand cu ora 18:30 la etajul 6 al cladiri Anchor Plaza de langa Plaza Romania Mall.
events.address: BD Timisoara, 26Z, Anchor Plaza, 6th floor Array

events.name: Art Bytes at the Walters
events.about:
Art has the power to bring people from diverse backgrounds together for enjoyment, discovery and learning. In this spirit, Baltimore will hold Art Bytes, a hackathon where technology and creative communities work together to build programs and applications inspired by art or to address specific challenges faced by museums. This will be Baltimore’s, and perhaps the nation’s, first art museum hackathon. 

This event will be at the Walters Art Museum from July 27–July 29. On Friday evening, July 27, staff from Baltimore’s museum community will present specific challenges or ideas that they would like solved—from how to use technology to experience a collection to how to virtually access archives. Over the course of the weekend, technologists, innovators, scholars and artists will coalesce into teams in the Walters’ Sculpture Court to design and develop their solution. Participants will be able to visit the museum’s galleries for inspiration throughout the weekend. On Sunday afternoon, July 29, leaders of the technology and innovation communities will judge which teams were the most successful. The experience of Art Bytes will be captured on video, and the team solutions displayed at Walters the following week.

 

Where: The Walters Art Museum, Sculpture Court

When: Friday, July 27–Sunday, July 29

     Friday, July 27, 5–9 p.m.

     Saturday, July 28, 10 a.m.–midnight

     Sunday, July 29, 10 a.m.–5 p.m.

Price: Free

events.name: AT&T Mobile App Hackathon - Los Angeles
events.about:
Have an app idea or need an app built for your business?

Mobile App Hackathon is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program and Apigee that is designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to build apps/mobile apps, get fed, compete for prizes across different categories and most importantly: meet new people and scout for teammates to work on new or current projects. Our hackathon will introduce you to the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.

As far as platforms are concerned, feel free to code in the language you feel most comfortable, whether its Objective C, Java, Javascript, HTML, C #, Dot Net, or XNA. Even if you are rusty with your programming, we will have live developer support from local senior developers as well as from AT&T to help you code that much faster.


Event Schedule.  The following is a list of the weekends agenda:

  • 6PM - Friday Evening - Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating which leads into idea pitches and team formation.
  • 7PM - Friday Evening - Lightning talks.
  • 8PM - Friday Evening - Idea pitches and team formation. Pitch your ideas and form teams or just start coding with your preformed teams.
  • 12AM - Friday Evening - End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!
  • 10AM - Saturday Morning - The fun continues with an all day hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed the night before to produce the app. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution. 
  • 1PM - Saturday Afternoon - Lunch
  • 7PM - Saturday Evening- Dinner
  • 12AM - Saturday Evening - End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!
  • 10AM - Sunday Morning - The fun continues with the final six (6) hours of the hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday to produce the app. Senseis will be available throughout the final hours to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 4PM.
  • 1PM - Sunday Afternoon - Lunch
  • 4PM - Sunday Evening - Promptly at 4PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.

Prizes. The following prizes are experiential and geared towards accelerating you towards a successful business as well as expanding your network and industry knowledge:

  • Best Hackathon Overall App 
    • 1st Place - $500 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Small service from Github for each team member
    • 2nd Place - $300 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Micro service from Github for each team member
    • 3rd Place - $200 in Gift Cards for the team and six (6) months of Micro service from Github for each team member

Judging Criteria. Apps will be judged based on the the criteria below and weighted accordingly.  

  • 33% Weight - Ability to clearly articulate what your app does
  • 33% Weight - Originality of idea
  • 33% Weight - Technically challenging implementation

 

 Hackathon Speakers

 

Alex Donn, a Senior Marketing Manager with the AT&T Developer Program, is based out of sunny Seattle! His passion is educating developers young and old about mobile application development best practices through events like hackathons that fuse the collective interests of multiple technology and business leaders. 

 Josh Hollenbeck, a Senior Software Developer for CitrusByte, has been programming since age 11 shortly after the families first amiga computer while growing up. He has worked on numerous client projects for established companies and start-ups; and is armed with a vast language skill-set and quick ability to tackle any area of unknown.
 
Lou Gazzola, a Marketing Manager in Developer Relations at RIM, has helped create marketing programs to excite and build the BlackBerry Developer community. Being a developer himself, he’s been able to create key events like the BBM Hackathon in New York and is currently focused on exciting the BlackBerry Developer community to create applications for the over 75 million BlackBerry Smartphone users.  Casey Rosenthal, a Consultant Engineer at Basho, where he installs and tests Riak clusters. He also provides training to clients so that they can do the same. As Chief Software Engineer for Port Forty Nine, Casey worked for NASA, Caltech, and JPL to engineer systems for storing and disseminating the image archives of space telescopes such as Hubble, Spitzer, and Chandra.

Senseis

   

Karim Varela, an Android developer with Fandango, has over eight years of mobile application development experience. In previous roles, Karim was an Android Engineer for Muve Music and the Android support lead within AT&T Mobilitys technical developer support team. Karim has also held various roles in the mobile games industry ranging from quality assurance and build engineering to porting, and networking engineering. 

Jorge Garifuna, founder and developer at mobile software company Garisoft.com, has 15 years of industry experience. His portfolio of technologies includes but are not limited to various programming languages, Web 2.0, a diverse number of Frameworks, countless of databases and mobile for popular platforms such as IOS, Android and BlackBerry.

Shikhir Singh is a Wireless Application Architect at Research in Motion (Blackberry). He was formerly a Lead Java Engineer at Lockheed Martin, Tackwholesale.com, and Sun Microsystems and loves Sencha Touch, jQuery Mobile, and PhoneGap/Webworks. 

Aaron Stannard, a Startup Developer Evangelist at Microsoft, evangelizes early stage web and software programs on Microsofts BizSpark program and the .NET platform. He has worked at SmartDraw.com and specializes in ASP.NET and C#. He holds a degree in Computer Science from Vanderbilt University.

Sponsors

events.name: Colorado Code For Communities: A Civic Hack-a-thon
events.about:
This July, the Partnership for Sustainable Communities and PlaceMatters will be hosting a civic hackfest in Denver to build and improve the latest apps that bring sustainability into the forefront of everyone’s lives.  These apps could help people and organizations answer questions like:

  • How do I get around the region quickly and affordably using any mix of transportation choices?
  • What is the true cost of my housing choice, including rent/mortgage and transportation?
  • Where are all the vacant lots and what’s the process of purchasing and developing these?
  • What does my neighborhood look like in terms of diversity and equity and how can I connect with my neighbors?

The event will bring together non-profits, government agencies, data providers, programmers, civic hackers, designers and anyone with an idea or stake in the future of our communities.  Over the weekend of July 27th, we’ll code and hack away at apps, data and visualizations that will improve the lives of people living, working and playing in the Denver region.  Bring your talents, ideas and creativity.  We’ll provide the data, expertise and nourishment.  Looking forward to seeing you this summer!

Go to http://codeforcommunities.org for more information.

events.name: iN-Motion Game Jam
events.about:
iN-MotionGameJam.com

 

 

iN-Motion Game Jam is a non-profit hackathon that raises the awareness of people with disabilities and the increasing movement of touchless control devices like Kinect. On July 27-29, 2012, iN-Motion Game Jam will be hosted at the Bethel Center at 2557 Alemany Blvd in San Francisco, CA. Vast Apps, Inc., a game and app developer start-up for smartphones, tablets, PCs, and motion devices, is the lead organizer of this event. Developers, artists, and other creative professionals will gather during a 48-hour period to make one or more games to target the usage for and awareness of people with disabilities. In partnership with Vast Apps, Inc., ZigFu, a middleware product developer, will be used to connect motion capturing devices with your computer in conjunction with Unity to create games or educational programs.

Sponsors include AT&T, Unity3D, Prime 31, YetiZen, Artbackr, and GameCloud. We are currently looking to increase participants and contributors for this 501(c)(3) non-profit fundraiser for Bethel Center. Please visit our website to become a sponsor, to participate or donate at www.in-motiongamejam.com.  

We are asking for artist and programmers that are interested in building educational games by using motion technology as your tool to come join just at Bethel Center. Willing participants from all levels of experience are welcome, from student and novice to experts and professionals.

Participants need to be familiar using Unity 3D game engine that supports both Javascript and C sharp language.  As an event that supports Unity, artists should be ready use 3D modeling tools like 3D Studio Max, Maya, SoftImage, or any software that allows obj or fbx files to be used in the game engine.  

If you are not brave enough to hack for 2 days straight, we welcome people to come see what the event is about. There will be a no cover charge; however, we encourage donations that will benefit the Bethel Center. We look forward to working with our participants and thank you in advance for your contribution.


Skill set Update: HTML5 developers are welcome!  Zigfu, the Kinect-to-computer middleware plugin, supports both Unity and HTML5 in the browser.  

Participants can be developers or designers from any level. Developers can use Unity and its supported languages (Javascript/C#), or they can also use HTML5. Designers can use the usual array of 3D modeling tools, but 2D games are also possible with both Unity and HTML5 in the browser.  If you'd like to develop with Kinect, or if you have Kinect-ideas to help people with disabilities -- then drop by, we'll help you get started and setup! 
 Prizes: Unity3D, GitHub, Prime31, ZigFu, plus many more

events.name: class of 2012 hackNY Fellows DemoFest
events.about: The 2012 class of hackNY Fellows is a stellar cohort of 32 student-hackers from across the country (and Canada!) working at some of NYCs best startups.  We couldnt be more proud of the group and all theyve done. (You might have seen our updates via @hackNY or our blog, http://hackNY.org/a/blog ). They independently organized teaching workshops to learn from each other; many of them launched new products or features at their startups which have already been announced; and still more have some great things theyd like to share with you. To that end, on July 27, 2012 hackNY presents the final DemoFest for the 2012 hackNY class, at NYUs Courant Institute. We hope very much that you can join!

events.name: Honolulu Answers Write-a-thon
events.about:
Got questions about your city? Write the answers, your way!


Have you ever gotten lost on a government website, or been confused about how its organized?

We have. So were launching a new website for the City and County of Honolulu thats simple, clean, and resident-focused.

Honolulu Answers will be as easy to use and accessible as asking a real person a question.

Be part of the first ever civic write-a-thon. Join us to write simple, easy-to-understand answers to your common questions, such as:

  • Where do I get a camping permit?
  • When is my garbage pick-up?
  • How do I renew my drivers license?

 

At the workshop, youll write short answers (1-2 paragraphs) to some of the most common questions from city residents. You dont need to be a writer to help. Answers will be non-technical and written as if you were answering a question asked by your neighbor.

Well provide food, tools to help you write, and expertise from local Honolulu writers. So please join us Saturday, July 28th, to improve Honolulu government!  

What to expect:

  • Bring your laptop or tablet if you have one. Well have paper for those who dont. 
  • City representatives will be on hand to answer any questions you may have while writing the quick answer.
  • Your post will earn an Author badge on Honolulu Answers.
  • The Write-a-thon will be aired on national TV at MSNBC!

Schedule:
  • 9 AM: Registration and Coffee
  • 9:30 AM: Opening session, including a demo of Honolulu Answers
  • 9:45 AM: Michael Levine of CivilBeat: Simple Writing
  • 10 AM: Writing templates and introduction of city staff
  • 10:15 AM: Start writing!
  • 12 PM: Lunch
  • 1:45 PM: Closing session
  • 2 PM: Head to bar to socialize further (optional)

events.name: Lusaka GDG: Hackathon for the Google Apps Developer Challenge
events.about:
Lusaka Google Developers Group, in association with BongoHive, presents...

The first-ever hackathon by Lusaka GTUG! Well be learning and hacking Google Technologies to create apps for the Google Apps Developer Challenge.

Who will be there: Developers, Designers

What will be hacked: Google Apps and Drive APIs and other Google technologies. We will be creating apps for the Google Apps Developer Challenge.

  1. Learn about Google Apps and Drive APIs

    • The event will include training on the major features of Google Apps and Drive APIs including other Google Technologies such as Android, Google Maps and more. Google tech enthusiasts will be on hand to help and to answer questions throughout the day.

  2. Build with Us or Build Your Own

    • Throughout the day, we will be building complete applications and aiding each other. If, on the other hand, you already have a great app idea for the Google Apps Developer Challenge, bring that idea with you to the hackathon. Even better, bring along anything you can prepare ahead of time (sketches, designs, webpage mockups, etc.) and use the time and information provided to develop your idea into a working application, then share it with the world.
    • At the end of the day, in the interest of time, well invite some of you to present your application with the group.

 

What Do I Need: We will provide facilities, power, food, refreshments, and experts to help you learn to use Google technologies and write your application. Just bring your laptop, ideas, and enthusiasm to complete the mix. Familiarize yourself with the APIs. Begin gathering ideas and maybe even a bit of coding and/or designing. Use the Hackathon to perfect your app.

Learning resources and tutorials on Google Technologies

Here are some links to learning resources, and tutorials to help you prepare for the hackathon and beyond. 

  • https://developers.google.com/google-apps/
  • Google Apps Provisioning API
  • Apps Script
  • Intro video
  • Creating a Script.
  • Google Drive SDK. 
  • Video from I/O.

 

Information about the Google Apps Developer Challenge can be found here.

 

Any updates relating to the hackathon will be posted on Twitter and Google+ using the hashtag, #lskghack (#lskghack on Google+).

Come and be a part of awesomeness!!!

events.name: Londinium MMXII Hackathon
events.about:
This summer, the worlds eyes are all on London’s summer of sports.

We expect an increasing volume of social media that generates huge amount of data. Tons of visitors as well as Londoners will be overwhelmed by variety of information. This is a great opportunity for technologists to analyse and visualise such information, as well as create new devices and apps to amplify, manage and make sense of the data in interesting ways.

We are organising a “Hackathon” (“Hack” + “Marathon”) where graphic designers , programmers, journalists, sports enthusiasts, and anyone with cool ideas and data gather in one place during a weekend to create something cool, fun and useful around the theme of London and Sports. At the end of the event, each team or individual pitches their outcome in front of all the participants.

 

See more detail at our web page.

Please also track us at Lanyrd and Follow us on Twitter.

 

NOTE:  Tickets for Demo participants will be released seperately.

events.name: Adobe WebUp #7 Hackathon
events.about:
Daca vrei sa codezi alaturi de alti oameni pasionati de JavaScript si HTML atunci acest eveniment este pentru tine. Cu atat mai mult cu cat vei avea ocazia sa contribui cod la Brackets - un proiect open source de la Adobe.

Timp de 6 ore o sa ai ocazia sa dai ce este mai bun din tine. Vom avea pizza, cafea, si sucuri. Tu trebuie doar sa vii cu laptopul tau (Windows sau Mac OS) si cu chef de codat.

Lista de lectura obligatorie daca doresti sa participi la hackathon este:

  • Sa descarci Brackets de aici si sa te joci cu el ca sa vezi ce face.
  • Sa urmaresti videorile care vorbesc despre arhitectura de aici.
  • Sa arunci un ochi pe Wiki-ul Brackets
  • Sa arunci un ochi pe backlogul echipei Brackets.
  • Sa fi familiarizat cu GitHub.
events.address: BD Timisoara, 26Z, Anchor Plaza, 6th floor Array

events.name: Hack for Change 2012
events.about:
On July 28, we’re gathering 200 of the best minds in engineering and design to create apps for a better world.

Here’s the deal. While there’s an incredible amount of talent among engineers and designers in Silicon Valley, it isn’t being harnessed for good. We’re giving hackers the chance to see the incredible impact they can have if they devote their energy to changing the world – even for just a day.

Our vision is simple: anyone, anywhere should have the tools to change the world at their fingertips. We empower people every day with the tools on Change.org, and we’re hosting Hack for Change to help engineers and designers empower the communities around them.

Cash prizes will be awarded for the top apps, so make sure to save your spot at Hack for Change today. Registration is required!

events.name: Summer Android Hackathon
events.about:
I has been a good time after our last event, people has been busy, some people has crashed into holidays others have been progressing in their start-ups. So we think will be good to say welcome (back) again to an Android Hackaton.

We will keep the agenda open:

  • We would like to get back to hacking on the community projects from previous events
  • We would like to recap and play some videos of Google I/O 2012

events.name: Muther! of all Hackathons + WIPJam @ Mobile Moves Michigan
events.about:
We are stoked to be heading to Michigan for a WIPJam+ Muther! of all Hackathons. Make plans to join WIP and MTAM (the Mobile Technology Association of Michigan) at a great event in the Midwest.  Event will be held in conjunction with “Mobile Moves Michigan”, a Mobile Technology Symposium and Strategic Planning event. 

Monday, July 30 will be a WIPJam Day for Developers, featuring Unpanels, Discusion Groups, Storytellers and more.  And, as always, No PPT No Panels No Ties!

Monday will wrap with a networking reception and the start of the Muther! of all  Hackathon.   Tuesday will see the continuation of hacking, application pitching, judging, awards and prizes!

We are still seeking sponsors and speakers. Contact Teresa Ostman from WIP for more details.

events.name: Meet the Jammers! TransmediaSF Presents: Stars of the 1st Transmedia Jam
events.about:
Meet the Jammers!

Transmedia SF and Producers Guild of America Present:

The Stars of the 1st Transmedia Jam

 DRINKS, FOOD, NETWORKING AND PRESENTATIONS

Join us for an evening of presentations from our first Transmedia Jam weekend event.


If you've ever wanted to attend a hackathon/createathon weekend, but weren't sure what to expect, this is an event for you:  We bring back our judges and the stars of our first Transmedia Jam to share with our community the good, the bad and the ugly of what it takes to make a transmedia project in under 30 hours!  

Hear from our esteemed Judges about the review process and what they looked for in their selections. And a special presentation will also be made by the overall winner of the Transemdia Jam - and even we won't know who that is until just before the event begins ;-)

 


 

About the Jam:  The inaugural Transmedia Jam is a weekend event on July 20th-21nd, that encourage and inspires all jammers to play with media, platforms and new ways of storytelling.

 

In the spirit of Game Jams, Hackathons and the CineSport project, the Transmedia Jam will bring together storytellers of all stripes to create new transmedia projects from start and finish in the same weekend.

 

INsert Jam Logo and Link

 

Schedule:

6:00 - Doors Open for Drinks, Demos and Networking

6:30 - Transmedia SF introducing The Jam Project a casestudy the Transmedia 

            Jam

7:00 - Judges present their winning choices - and what they look for in a project.

7:30 - Top Jammer team presents their project.

8:00-9:00 Networking


Judges:


 

Jason Deadrich
CEO and Founder - Fordela
Jason is an Internet visionary and entrepreneur who started his career by leading the launch of LucasArts Entertainment's complex online system architecture in 1992. After gaining a wealth of technical knowledge and over a decade of digital media experience launching the media infrastructure of companies such as Mazingo Networks and Tranz-Send Broadcasting Company, Jason founded Fordela with the vision of creating an intuitive, scalable and cost-effective rich media management solution which could be offered as a cloud-based service. While pioneering the company into a space where dealing with all media is seamlessly and intuitively integrated into both enterprise infrastructure and commerce, Jason Deadrich also acts as a local industry leader, allowing his technical knowledge to be tapped as a community resource as he speaks at college campuses and technological conventions, and teaches students from the San Francisco Academy of Art.
www.fordela.com

David Austin
Sr. Director - Media Camp at Turner Broadcasting
David Austin has over 25 years of extensive product and corporate development experience in bringing a multitude of amazing products to consumer markets as well as identifying, acquiring and integrating a wealth of intellectual property, products and teams.
Prior to coming to Turner to help shape the future of media he was a Senior Director at Apple Inc for two stints totaling over 17 years. During his time there, David delivered a broad swath of consumer products working extensively with Senior Executive Management (including working directly with the late Steve Jobs on the original Keynote and iWork products).
In between stints at Apple he co-founded a startup and worked for a boutique venture capital firm. Since leaving Apple in 2009 he has had the privilege of being an investor, advisor, and board member to many angel and venture-backed startups.
David has a BS in Math and Computer Science and holds three patents.
www.mediacamp.com

 Steve KlettOnline Manger www.nvidia.comSteve joined NVIDIA in 2010 as Manager of 3DVisionLive.com. Previously, Steve worked at Future US as editor in chief of NVISION—The Official NVIDIA Magazine. He has written for a variety of consumer technology and entertainment publications, including Maximum PC, PC Gamer, and The Official Windows Magazine.

While not at work Steve can be found stalking insects with his digital SLR and macro lens, enjoying time in the great outdoors with his family, or at his computer playing the latest 3D videogames.

events.name: metaLAB Copyright Hackathon
events.about:
metaLAB Copyright Hackathon

Thursday - August 2

23 Everett Street, Cambridge MA 

 

What happens to copyright in the wild? How do we go about determining who owes what to whom when we go about making, remixing, and sharing? What resources do we turn to in understanding the tortured terms and contested boundaries of “intellectual property”?

On Thursday, August 2nd, join metaLAB for a day of copyright experimentation, hacking, and exploration.


Schedule

events.name: 2nd PinoyBBDev Hackathon 2012
events.about:
Why limit your self to a single storefront if you can have more! Maximize your skills by expanding your channels!  

 

Philippine BlackBerry Developer Group (PinoyBBDev) brings you PinoyBBDev Hackathon 2012, a two-day coding session that will turn your app ideas into reality. This aims to create awareness on the different technologies in creating applications for BlackBerry. It also show case the Filipino Talent not just in Asia but around the world. And lastly, to increase the Filipino Made Apps in the BlackBerry AppWorld. This years hackathon focuses on technologies supported by BlackBerry PlayBook andBlackBerry 10, the upcoming operating system for the new generation of BlackBerry devices. 

Adobe AIR using ActionScript, Flash or Flex

Android - repackage your Android apps for BlackBerry PlayBook and BlackBerry 10 using Java Android Runtime

Native with options to use Native SDK using C/C++/OpenGL, or Cascades (C++/Qt)

WebWorks using HTML5, CSS & Javascript

 

Prizes and Categories

Every participant will get a t-shirt and assorted BlackBerry items. On top of that, each WINNING team will receive two (2) BlackBerry 16gb Playbook and one (1) brand new BlackBerry Smartphone.

There will be a total of five (5) winning teams by the end of the event, one for each category. The categories are:

  • Best Android App
  • Best Adobe AIR App
  • Best Native App(NDK/Cascades)
  • Best WebWorks App
  • Best BlackBerry 10 App

 

Judging

Apps will be judged based on the criteria below and weighted accordingly:

  • 25% Viability of business model
  • 25% Design quality
  • 25% Originality of idea
  • 25% Fully functioning App
  • Each team will have 3 minutes to present their finished app

 

Schedule

1st Day - August 4, 2012

  • 7:30 am – 8:30 am : Registration and Breakfast
  • 8:30 am – 10:45 am : Introductions and presentation
  • 10:45 am – 12:00 pm : Lunch Break / Hacking Time

2nd Day - August 5, 2012

  • 2:00 pm : End of Hacking
  • 2:00 pm – 2:30 pm : Final touches / Presentation Materials
  • 2:30 pm – 4:30 pm : 3 minute presentations
  • 4:30 pm – 6:00 pm : Awarding and closing

FAQ

 

Is registration free?

- Yes, registration is free.

How many people are expected to attend the event?

- Maximum of 150 participants will be accepted as participants.

What is the maximum number of members in a team?

- A team is allowed to have at most, and is recommended to have, 3 members.

Can I attend hackathon without joining a team?

-Yes, you can. You can also decide whether to join other teams during the pitching session which will happen before the actual coding starts.

Can I join even I dont have any experience in BlackBerry development?

- Yes, as long as you have basic/general knowledge on the supported technologies. Mentors will be available during the event to help you anyway.

What are the requirements?

- The only requirement is to create an application that works with the BlackBerry Playbook/BB10 Alpha Device. Other than that, your imagination is the limit.

Can I come to the event with a finished app?

- Unfortunately no. Only apps developed during the hackathon are eligible to win prizes. Although you can already start planning even before the event.

What should I bring to the hackathon?

- You need to bring your own laptops and any type of software or device which you use to program or design the applications. You also need to bring and present your registration voucher at the registration booth. If you or your team decides to spend the night at the venue, you may also bring pillows, sleeping bags, toiletries, and other necessary stuff.

I don’t have a BlackBerry PlayBook or BlackBerry 10 Dev Alpha Device, how am I going to test?

- Experts from BlackBerry will be helping teams with devices and guidance on how to install your app on the BlackBerry PlayBook or BlackBerry 10 Dev Alpha Device. Simulators are also available for you to test your app right in your laptops.

Are we required to pitch in our app ideas?

- No, teams or individuals may choose to pitch in their app ideas (particularly if they are still looking for team members), or not.

Will the event provide food and drinks?

- Yes, food and non-alcoholic drinks will be provided during the event For two days, breakfast, lunch, dinner (first day only), snacks, coffee and others will be provided.

 

 *If you wish to apply for a BlackBerry AppWorld Vendor Account, please bring a one(1) valid Government ID(Drivers license/Passport/SSS ID etc). We have an on-site registration with express approval.

events.name: GDG Lusaka: Part 2 of the Hackathon for the Google Apps Developer Challenge
events.about:
Google Developers Group Lusaka presents...

 

Part two of GDG Lusaka Hackathon for the Google Apps Developer Challenge! Well be learning and hacking Google Technologies to create apps for the Google Apps Developer Challenge.

Who will be there: Developers, Designers

When and Where: The hackathon will take place on Saturday, 4th August, 2012 from 09:00 AM to 05:00 PM. It will be held at BongoHive, CDC Building, opposite the Chinese Embassy, Long Acres, Lusaka. View on Map

What will be hacked: Google Apps and Drive APIs and other Google technologies. We will be creating apps for the Google Apps Developer Challenge.

  1. Learn about Google Apps and Drive APIs
    • Just like the before, the event will include training on the major features of Google Apps and Drive APIs including other Google Technologies such as Android, Google Maps and more. Google tech enthusiasts will be on hand to help and to answer questions throughout the day.
  2. Build with Us or Build Your Own
    • Throughout the day, we will be building applications from ideas from the first part of the hackathon. If, on the other hand, you already have a great app idea for the Google Apps Developer Challenge, bring that idea with you to the hackathon, and we will help you get started on it. Even better, bring along anything you can prepare ahead of time (sketches, designs, webpage mockups, etc.) and use the time and information provided to develop your idea into a working application, then share it with the world.
    • At the end of the day, in the interest of time, well have some demos.

What Do I Need: We will provide facilities, power, food, refreshments, and experts to help you learn to use Google technologies and write your application. Just bring your laptop, ideas, and enthusiasm to complete the mix. Familiarize yourself with the APIs. Begin gathering ideas and maybe even a bit of coding and/or designing. Use the Hackathon to perfect your app.

Learning resources and tutorials on Google Technologies

  • Here are some links to learning resources, and tutorials to help you prepare for the hackathon and beyond.
    • Google Apps Platform
    • Google Apps Provisioning API
    • Apps Script
    • Intro video
    • Creating a Script
    • Google Drive SDK
    • Video from I/O

Information about the Google Apps Developer Challenge can be found here.

Any updates relating to the hackathon will be posted on Twitter and Google+ using the hashtag, #lskghack (#lskghack on Google+).


Come and be a part of awesomeness!!!

events.name: Enyo Hackathon - Silicon Valley
events.about:
The Enyo Hackathon - Silicon Valley is the first hackathon in the SF Bay Area focused on Enyo-based applications.  It is a free working event for developers, designers, and testers to build web and device applications with the Enyo Development Framework.

The event is sponsored by the Developer Relations Team. All experience levels are welcome, but you’ll definitely get the most value from this event if you’ve already got a solid JavaScript background and a drive to create something with Enyo. We encourage both solo and team projects so be prepared to hit the ground working on an application during the event.  Individuals and teams are welcome to present their project efforts at the end of the day. 

Well be keeping our eyes out for folks who are doing great things with Enyo that promote the project and help their fellow developers.  Contributions could include an app, widget, sample code, documentation improvement, bug fix, or anything else you can point to an explain how it benefits Enyo. 

Space is limited.  First come first served. Please register now.

 

Event Details:

Cost: Free

Bring:  Laptop, mobile devices for development. Any platform will do, Windows, Linux or Mac OSX

Time: 9:30am- 8:00pm

Questions:  Julie Apffel  julie.apffel@palm.com

 

Agenda:

09:30 am: Doors Open

09:30-10:00 am:  Networking and Breakfast

10:00-10:15 am:  Welcome by Gray Norton

10:15-10:30 am:  Presentation by Hal Saville of Digihal

10:30-10:45 am:  Presentation by Ryan Rix

10:45 am:  HACKING BEGINS

12:30-01:30 pm:  LUNCH BROUGHT IN and provided for all attendees

01:30-06:00 pm:  HACKING continues

06:00 - 07:30 pm: App Presentations, Prizes, Pizza, and Drinks

08:00 pm:  Hackathon finished!

events.name: Adobe WebUp #8
events.about:
A opta editie Adobe WebUp va fi totalmente informala. De ce? Pentru ca este vara, pentru ca este foarte cald, pentru ca este concediu si nu in ultimul rand, pentru ca putem :D.

Asa dar, ne vom vedea la Curtea Berarilor incepand cu 8 seara in data de 9 August!

Pentru ca este o intalnire formala nu avem sesiuni ca deobice. Totusi Alexandru Vladutu vrea sa faca o demonstratie de VI (si sa explice de ce este cel mai tare editor de pe fata pamantului :D). De asemenea vreau sa vorbim despre urmatorul hackathon.

Cei care au fost prezenti la ultima editie stiu deja acest lucru. Pentru ceilalti, atentie mare :). Vrem sa facem un hackathon in toamna care sa aiba ca rezultat un site web modern (responsive design and friends) pentru o (sau mai multe) fundatie/ONG. Vom crea siteul de la zero, site care va fi nu numai functional si modern, dar si aratos. Nu ne intereseaza partea de server side, ne vom focaliza doar pe HTML/CSS/JS.

Prima etapa este sa facem o lista de ONG-uri/fundatii care credeti ca ar fi cool sa aiba acest site facut gratis. Pentru sugestii folositi cu incredere pagina Facebook a Adobe WebUp si puneti un comentariu la mesajul cu acelasi continut: http://www.facebook.com/AdobeWebUp.

Cam acestea ar fi temele de discutie prestabilite. Avand bere in program si o locatie relaxata sunt sigur ca vom mai avea si alte subiecte de discutie interesante.

events.name: Startup Tucson Hackathon, a Startup Weekend Tucson Pre-event
events.about:
Welcome to the first ever Startup Tucson Hackathon! We are dedicated to making this an exciting, unique event, something that can help push Tucson forward. 

http://startuptucson.com/hackathon

 

Startup Tucson Hackathon - August 10th-11th

Please join us on August 10th for a hackathon in sunny Tucson! 
Work in teams, develop something over 24 hours, and compete for glory!

Build with Us or Build Your Own

Throughout the day, we will be building a simple chunk of code from start to finish. A script, a prototype, whatever can be done. Nothing huge, the important point is to finish it and have fun. If you already have a great idea for what to build, bring that idea with you to the hackathon. Even better, bring along anything you can prepare ahead of time (sketches, designs, webpage mockups, etc.) and use the time and information provided to develop your idea into a working application, then share it with the world. 

At 3pm Saturday, well invite you to share your application with the group. Judges and attendees will rate the apps, and there will be prizes and glory for the winners. Swag for everyone else.

What Do I Need?

We will provide facilities, power, food, refreshments, and experts to help you code and write your application. Just bring your laptop, ideas, and enthusiasm to complete the mix.

When and Where?

The Startup Tucson Hackathon will take place over 24 hours starting at 4pm on Friday August 10th. It will be held at Spoke6 on 6th St. and 6th Ave.

Why?

We want to bring Tucsons developers TOGETHER. Plain and simple. The internet goes only so far. The synergy that happens when coders get together at a hackathon is a unique, exciting, and beautiful thing. This is your chance to hack together that crazy idea youve had in the back of your mind. Make it happen!

General Schedule:

Friday August 10th

4PM - 7PM - Registration. Come and get your swag and badges early. Doors are open and coding can officially begin at 3pm.
7PM - Dinner & Reception. We will host a feast and introduce the teams and get to know each other. Its about code, but its also about coding with each other!
9PM - Feel free to go home and relax...or for the young and full of energy, Spoke6 will be open ALL NIGHT to let the coding juices flow.

Saturday August 11th

7AM - Breakfast is served
Noon - Lunch is served
3PM - Presentation time! Time to show off the hard work youve put in the 23 hours! Youll present your product quickly to our judges, who will give you feedback. The attendees and judges will vote on the best product and idea.
3:45PM - Awards Ceremony. A short awards ceremony for those whove won (prizes will be announced shortly).
4 PM - Go home and get some sleep! You deserve it!

 

 

How You Can Help

Sponsors

Are you a business or organization that could use some visibility in the Tucson tech scene? We are currently looking for sponsors who would be willing to help pay for event costs. We have multiple levels of sponsorship available. Sponsors will get prime visibility on the Startup Tucson website, in media outlets, and at the event itself. This is a great way to position yourself at the cutting edge of Tucsons development community!

Promoters

Are you or do you know a group or organization that we could partner with to promote the event? A computer users group? Student group at the U of A? The more grassroots support we can get, the better it can be!

Judges and Mentors

Are you tech/business savvy? Are you opinionated? If so, please come and judge our attendees work. We are looking for pillars of the community who can give mentorship and advice during the day, and also be vocal during the final presentations.

Volunteers

Are you free to help organize the event? Are you adept in blogging or social media? Do you have media connections we can use to get the word out? Can you go to costco and buy copious amounts of caffeine and snacks? If you can help in any small way, it could make a big difference.

Feedback and Support

And here is the proposed format. We want to know what YOU want from a hackathon. If you have any ideas on how you can improve it, were all ears!

 

We need the support of the ENTIRE community to make this happen. Please email chris@enemyhideout.com if you think you can help, or if you have any questions.

events.name: Windows 8 Boot to VHD Event - Denver (August 10, 2012)
events.about:
My team is hosting Windows 8 Boot Camps / Hackathons to help get developers up to speed on Windows 8 Development.  I may not be a developer, but I can still help the developer community get their machines up and running on Windows 8 today without having to wipe out their existing Windows 7 installation.

Since the actual RTM bits are not quite available yet, I will have bootable thumb drives with Windows 8 Release Preview and Windows Server 2012 Release Candidate.  In addition, I will also provide VHD files that have Windows Server 2012 Release Candidate and Windows 8 Release Preview preinstalled so that we can configure your machine with Boot to VHD (no repartitioning required and keeps your existing OS intact).

The only requirement for your computer is that you have Windows 7 or higher installed (required for Boot to VHD) and no drive encryption enabled (e.g. bitlocker, etc.).

If you would like to grab the files prior to arriving at the event, I have put the preinstalled VHDs here: http://aka.ms/hwitcampfiles.  Please download the ISO images here: http://aka.ms/hwws2012 and http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/windows-8/download.

The event will take place at the Denver Microsoft Office located at 7595 Technology Way, Suite 400, Denver, CO 80237.

Date: Friday, August10, 2012

Start Time: 4:45PM

End Time: 7:00 PM

events.name: AT&T Mobile App Hackathon - Miami
events.about:
Have an app idea or need an app built for your business?

Mobile App Hackathon is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program that is designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to build apps/mobile apps, get fed, compete for prizes across different categories and most importantly: meet new people and scout for teammates to work on new or current projects. Our hackathon will introduce you to the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.

As far as platforms are concerned, feel free to code in the language you feel most comfortable, whether its Objective C, Java, Javascript, HTML, C #, Dot Net, or XNA. Even if you are rusty with your programming, we will have live developer support from local senior developers as well as from AT&T to help you code that much faster.


Event Schedule.  The following is a list of the weekends agenda:

  • 6PM - Friday Evening - Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating which leads into idea pitches and team formation.
  • 7PM - Friday Evening - Lightning talks.
  • 8PM - Friday Evening - Idea pitches and team formation. Pitch your ideas and form teams or just start coding with your preformed teams.
  • 12AM - Friday Evening - End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!
  • 10AM - Saturday Morning - The fun continues with an all day hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed the night before to produce the app. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution. 
  • 1PM - Saturday Afternoon - Lunch
  • 7PM - Saturday Afternoon - Dinner
  • 12AM - Saturday Evening - End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!
  • 10AM - Sunday Morning - The fun continues with the final six (6) hours of the hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday to produce the app. Senseis will be available throughout the final hours to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 4PM.
  • 1PM - Sunday Afternoon - Lunch
  • 4PM - Sunday Evening - Promptly at 4PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.

Prizes. To be announced!

Judging Criteria. Apps will be judged based on the the criteria below and weighted accordingly.  

  • 33% Weight - Ability to clearly articulate what your app does
  • 33% Weight - Originality of idea
  • 33% Weight - Technically challenging implementation

 

Speakers

Alex Donn is a Developer Evangelist with the AT&T Developer Program and is based out of sunny Seattle! His passion is educating developers young and old about mobile application development best practices through events like hackathons that fuse the collective interests of multiple technology and business leaders. Thomas Packert is the Chief Technology Officer at CareCloud, was formerly Vice President of Information Management at Visible Assets, Inc., where he led the development of proprietary radio frequency ID (RFID) solutions to solve healthcare supply chain influences using open source software development tools.

 

 
Sean M. Mcnamara is the Chief Technology Officer at LegalFile, was formerly the Director of Software Development at Blue Dot Solutions where he played key roles in both, product development and professional services. He has over ten years of experience in building enterprise mobile solutions.

Brian Breslin is an active community leader in the South Florida tech scene, having founded Refresh Miami, the largest tech meetup group in South Florida. He has been involved in web development for over twelve years and is heavily involved in social media and social networks.

  

 
Milana V. Kuznetsova is the CEO at ESENEM and a lawyer, having served in the civil and criminal practice areas, and an experienced law practice management and technology entrepreneur. She is a frequent lecturer and published authority, advising on law practice management, technology, and ethical considerations.

    
 
 

Senseis

   
Andrej Kostresevic is the founder of New Frontier Nomads, and has more than a decade of development experience. He was the lead mobile develper at Myxer.com, where he was in charge of all of Myxers mobile apps - including an iPhone app and its Android counterpart, which currently have over 10 million downloads collectively. Bryce Kerley is a Developer Advocate at Basho, is a highly skilled Rails developer. Prior to joining Basho, he worked as an independent Rails developer, consulting on everything from AJAZ to ZFS.
   
   

Sponsors

events.about:
Dear Students,

 

You have an opportunity to participate in an amazing event taking place next week starting August 10, 2012 at 6:00 p.m. We are looking for 25 students interested in volunteering at the AT&T Mobile App Hackathon taking place at the UM Life Science & Technology Park.

Sunday, August 12, 2012 9:15a.m. to 6:00 p.m.

*Students will only be required to work a six hour shift each day

 

See event details below


Have an app idea or need an app built for your business?

AT&T Mobile App Hackathon Miami is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program, ESENEM, South Florida Android Developers Group, and Miami Ruby Brigade. It is designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to share ideas, work together and build great mobile applications! Our hackathon will introduce you to some of the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.

As far as platforms are concerned, feel free to code in the language you feel most comfortable, whether its Objective C, Java, Javascript, HTML, C #, Dot Net, or XNA. Even if you are rusty with your programming, we will have live developer support from local senior developers as well as from AT&T to help you code that much faster.

We Supply: Quick presentations and code samples that help to bootstrap your hacking, food to keep you going, and caffeine to keep you awake. The first 150 developers will receive free zeemote devices in order to assist in your development.  In addition we will have NFC devices on site for you to test with.

 

You Bring: Your laptop, skills & ideas. Come with a collaborative, team focused mindset and/or team up in advance on Twitter/Facebook/Google+ via the #atthack hashtag. Whether you are a backend person and code in Ruby/PHP/.NET or are a designer and only work with Illustrator, you are invited to attend this event. Every group needs a good balance of talent and your development skills are needed!


 

Event Schedule.  The following is a list of the weekends agenda:

 

  • 6PM - Friday Evening - Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating which leads into idea pitches and team formation.

 

  • 7PM - Friday Evening - Lightning talks.

 

  • 8PM - Friday Evening - Idea pitches and team formation. Pitch your ideas and form teams or just start coding with your preformed teams.

 

  • 12AM - Friday Evening - End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!

 

  • 10AM - Saturday Morning - The fun continues with an all day hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed the night before to produce the app. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution. 

 

  • 1PM - Saturday Afternoon - Lunch

 

  • 7PM - Saturday Afternoon - Dinner

 

  • 10PM - Saturday Evening - End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!

 

  • 10AM - Sunday Morning - The fun continues with the final six (6) hours of the hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday to produce the app. Senseis will be available throughout the final hours to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 4PM.
  • 1PM - Sunday Afternoon - Lunch

 

  • 4PM - Sunday Evening - Promptly at 4PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.

 

Prizes. More to be announced!

 

  • Best Hackathon Overall App 
    • 1st Place - $500 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Small service from Github for each team member
    • 2nd Place - $300 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Micro service from Github for each team member
    • 3rd Place - $200 in Gift Cards for the team and six (6) months of Micro service from Github for each team member
  • Best App using AT&T APIs
    • 1st Place - A Sierra Wireless 4G LTE Elevate device and 1 Month of 1GB DataConnect Service (Max 3)
  • Best Use of Sphero SDK - $500 Cash, plus $500 additional if the app is launched to iTunes or Android store - Sphero is the first robotic ball gaming device that you control with a tilt, touch, or swing from your smartphone or tablet. You can even use Sphero as a controller for on-screen gameplay. This means big things for you developers. Use the Sphero iOS or Android SDK to create a unique app, hack, or something entirely different. 

 


 

Judging Criteria. Apps will be judged based on the the criteria below and weighted accordingly.  

 

  • 33% Weight - Ability to clearly articulate what your app does

 

  • 33% Weight - Originality of idea

 

  • 33% Weight - Technically challenging implementation

events.name: Context.IO Presents the LSRC Hackathon
events.about:
Context.IO is excited to bring you the first ever official Lone Star Ruby Conference overnight hackathon! We're bringing together national and local APIs for a night of hacking, fun, and prizes. Obviously, this event will be open to attendees of LSRC, but we're also opening it up to anyone who wants in on the fun. We'll have APIs such as our own (Context.IO), Twilio, Sendgrid, and Searchify coming together to demo their APIs, help you generate ideas and support you as you hack into the night. We'll also be providing tons of tasty food and drink and all the energy you'll need to create something amazing overnight. All of our APIs will be strong supporters of Ruby, but this event is wide open to programmers of any language. And there will be some SWEET prizes; SendGrid is giving away an awesome Sphero for the best hack on their API. The big winners get a MacBook Pro Retina Display, and we'll have a sweet Thunderbolt Display for the 2nd place winners!

Our theme will be all about communications. We live in a world of pings, push notifications and 24 hour information overload. What can you build to help lighten the crushing load this brings into our lives? How can you leverage these technologies to improve the flow of communication we all have to manage every day?

 

JUDGES ANNOUNCED!

Here's our amazing line-up of judges!

 

JOSHUA BAER:

Joshua Baer is the founder and CEO of OtherInbox and has been working to empower consumers on the Internet and improve email marketing best practices for more than a decade. In 1996 Baer founded SKYLIST, one of the first email marketing companies, in his college dorm room. In 1998 he co-authored RFC 2369, a technical standard for unsubscribe that has been adopted by Google, Microsoft and Yahoo. Baer first conceived of OtherInbox as a solution to his own email management problems. He soon realized that it was also an opportunity to address many of the pains of email marketing while still protecting the consumer’s privacy. Baer holds Computer Science and Information Decision Systems degrees from Carnegie Mellon University and lives in Austin, TX with his wife and three children.

 

MICKEY RISTROPH: 

Mickey Ristroph is the CTO of Mutual Mobile, guiding Mutual Mobile’s research and development efforts for next-generation tools and platforms. He consults on the strategic direction of the company and has been the driving force behind Mutual Mobile’s ability to extend both the technological and market impact of the mobile platform.

Before founding Mutual Mobile, Mickey wrote software for a global data mining initiative by the Department of Defense, designed the infrastructure and reporting tools for automated high frequency financial trading systems, and performed computational research in bioinformatics. Mickey co-founded AccessAble Systems, LLC, for which he won the Dell Social Innovation Challenge, and made it to the finals of the DARPA Grand Challenge for his work on autonomous vehicles. He has also designed multiple games and utilities for the iPhone, including the successful telephony app SparkPhone.

At Mutual Mobile, Mickey advises clients on enterprise mobility and leads the consulting team to devise both short- and long-term strategies for every customer’s mobile initiatives. His intimacy with financial services and Big Data has enabled him to deploy secure, highly scalable mobile solutions for such organizations as Cisco and BancVue.

 

JON LOYENS:

Jon Loyens is the Vice President of Engineering for Products at Bazaarvoice. He's responsible for the engineering and delivery of Bazaarvoice's Software as a Service User Generated Content products.

Jon previously founded and was Director of the Labs group at Bazaarvoice, which is charged with creating innovative new pilot products and beta technologies in the user generated content and social media space.

Before Bazaarvoice, Jon built a world class User Interface technology group and grew revenue in the implementation space as CTO of Thinktiv, a product management and design consultancy in Austin, TX.

 

JOE BOUTROS

Joe Boutros leads Indeed Labs, the startup within a startup at Indeed, the world's leading destination for jobs.  He spends his day balancing between technical and product functions, and helps inject early stage startup ethos into everything he touches.

Previously, Joe was a technical consultant to startups, both independently and as a part of Thinktiv.  He also spent time as a product hacker at both B-Side Entertainment and Trilogy Software.

Joe holds a degree in Computer Science from Case Western Reserve University, and lives in Austin, TX where he also runs a small real estate investment company.

 

SCHEDULE:

7 PM: ARRIVAL AND REGISTRATION - Dinner will be served. Come and find teammates, discuss potential ideas and network before the API presentations.

7:30 PM: API DEMOS -  Each participating API will have a dedicated representative in attendance to demo the API and help you get started with your hacks. Demos will be 5 mins each.

8:30 PM - 12:00 NOON on Sunday the 12th - HACKING! You'll have 15.5 hours to build something awesome. Work the whole night through or take a quick break to sleep - up to you! Drinks and snacks will be available all night long and breakfast will be served in the morning. 

12:00 NOON on Sunday August 12th - DEMOS! You'll have 3 minutes to demo your hack. Points will be given for originality, functionality and for mashing up as many participating APIs as you can. All hacks must make use of at least one participating API but are free to use whatever outside resources they choose.

1:30 PM - 2:00 PM August 12th - JUDGING!

2:00 PM August 12th - WINNERS ANNOUNCED! 

Thanks to our awesome sponsors and participating APIs!

events.name: AT&T Mobile App Hackathon - Denver
events.about:
Have an app idea or need an app built for your business?

Mobile App Hackathon is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program that is designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to build apps/mobile apps, get fed, compete for prizes across different categories and most importantly: meet new people and scout for teammates to work on new or current projects. Our hackathon will introduce you to the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.

As far as platforms are concerned, feel free to code in the language you feel most comfortable, whether its Objective C, Java, Javascript, HTML, C #, Dot Net, or XNA. Even if you are rusty with your programming, we will have live developer support from local senior developers as well as from AT&T to help you code that much faster.


Event Schedule.  The following is a list of the weekends agenda:


      Thursday, August 16th.      

  • 6PM - Thursday Evening - Intro/kickoff speech by the CTO of Full Contact, First idea individual pitches, then discuss, form teams, and refine your ideas. 
  • 7PM - Thursday Evening - Team pitches. Assignment for 8PM: discuss intended audience and monetization. 
  • 8PM - Thursday Evening - Team pitches focused on intended audience and monetization. Assignment for 9PM: sketch/brainstorm app UI. Go wild with your app capabilities! On Friday, we will cover technologies that can help you realize your app features/dreams.
  • 9PM - Thursday Evening - Team pitches focused on UI. End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!
      Friday, August 17th. Dinner will be served.
  • 6PM - Friday Evening - Lightning talks.
  • 7PM - Friday Evening - Begin to code and work with your teams. 
  • 11PM - Friday Evening -  End of the night. Go home, get some rest and come back the next day refreshed!
      Saturday, August 18th. Breakfast and lunch will be served.
  • 10AM - Saturday Morning - The fun continues with the final six (6) hours of the hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday to produce the app. Senseis will be available throughout the final hours to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 4PM.
  • 1PM - Saturday Afternoon - Take a break, stretch, and enjoy some lunch.
  • 4PM - Saturday Evening - Promptly at 4PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.

Prizes. The following prizes are experiential and geared towards accelerating you towards a successful business as well as expanding your network and industry knowledge:

  • Best Hackathon Overall App 
    • 1st Place - $500 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Small service from Github for each team member
    • 2nd Place - $300 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Micro service from Github for each team member
    • 3rd Place - $200 in Gift Cards for the team and six (6) months of Micro service from Github for each team member
  • Best App using AT&T APIs
    • 1st Place - A Sierra Wireless 4G LTE Elevate device and 1 Month of 1GB DataConnect Service (Max 3)


Judging Criteria. Apps will be judged based on the the criteria below and weighted accordingly.  

  • 33% Weight - Ability to clearly articulate what your app does
  • 33% Weight - Originality of idea
  • 33% Weight - Technically challenging implementation
Social Media. 
  • Follow us @hackathonlive for live updates and photos from the event
  • Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/AttMobileAppHackathon

 

Speakers

 

Alex Donn is a Senior Marketing Manager with the AT&T Developer Program, is based out of sunny Seattle! His passion is educating developers young and old about mobile application development best practices through events like hackathons that fuse the collective interests of multiple technology and business leaders. Dan Lynn is the CTO and Co-Founder of FullContact, a TechStars Boulder 2011 graduate which is solving the worlds contact information problem. Dans background includes product development, continuous delivery, big data, data science, and music.
Danny Newman is the founder and CEO of Roximity, as well as the CEO of Contxts and ID345. He was also the Founder and CEO of Mobiom and zuvo, two mobile applications that were inspired by his own mobile app needs. 

Scott Davis is founder of Thirstyhead.com, a training company that specializes in Groovy and Grails. He is also the owner of Davisworld Consulting, Inc. and is also involved in the Boulder Java Users Group and the Grails User Group.
   

 
 

Senseis

Greg Davis is a User Experience Designer for Pearson Education where he uses his blend of creativity and front-end expertise to design, build and test interfaces; as well as rapidly prototype new concepts for user testing and iteration. Hes also the principle and owner at Monsterworks Design and holds a BFA from the University of Colorado at Denver.

Drew Dahlman is a freelance interactive designer and developer with a focus in web apps and cross-platform applications. He specializes in PhoneGap/Cordova development using HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript. 

 
Michael Rose is a Senior Backend Engineer at FullContact Inc.. He specializes in Bigdata, with a focus on Hadoop/HBase. He also has experience with Groovy and Grails programming as well as Java, Scala, and Clojure. He is currently working on his Masters degree in Computer Science.


   

 

Sponsors

events.name: Windows 8 Boot to VHD Event - Irvine (August 17, 2012)
events.about:
My team is hosting Windows 8 Boot Camps / Hackathons to help get developers up to speed on Windows 8 Development.  I may not be a developer, but I can still help the developer community get their machines up and running on Windows 8 today without having to wipe out their existing Windows 7 installation.

Since the actual RTM bits are not quite available yet, I will have bootable thumb drives with Windows 8 Release Preview and Windows Server 2012 Release Candidate.  In addition, I will also provide VHD files that have Windows Server 2012 Release Candidate and Windows 8 Release Preview preinstalled so that we can configure your machine with Boot to VHD (no repartitioning required and keeps your existing OS intact).

The only requirement for your computer is that you have Windows 7 or higher installed (required for Boot to VHD) and no drive encryption enabled (e.g. bitlocker, etc.).

If you would like to grab the files prior to arriving at the event, I have put the preinstalled VHDs here: http://aka.ms/hwitcampfiles.  Please download the ISO images here: http://aka.ms/hwws2012 and http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/windows-8/download.

The event will take place at the Irvine Microsoft Office located at 3 Park Plaza, Suite 1600, Irvine, CA 92614.

Date: Friday, August 17, 2012

Start Time: 4:45PM

End Time: 7:00 PM

events.name: Hack the Social Web with Facebook & Heroku
events.about:
Join Facebook and Heroku for a two-day Hackathon focused on helping developers build and deploy social web apps, August 18th & 19th at the Heroku office in San Francisco!


A Social Hackathon
We’ll be doing more than creating social apps. On Saturday evening, teams will have the opportunity to demo their products to the whole crowd for feedback. Get real time, actionable input on what you’ve been working on and provide feedback to others. You’ll have time on Sunday to improve, fix and clean up your app before the judging round.

Not sure what to build? No problem. We’ll have some suggestions for apps we’d like to see.

Need a break from hacking? We’ll have video games, pool, ping pong, and a zen room available.


Hack to Win
Judges from Facebook and Heroku will each choose winning teams to be awarded with an assortment of prizes to help launch your app.

In addition, there will be one “people’s choice” winner judged by attendees who walks away with fame, notoriety, and bragging rights.

We can’t wait to see what you build!

events.name: Hack the Future 5
events.about:
Are you a 5th-12th grade student who wants to learn more about computers than they teach you in school? Then its time to start teaching yourself! 

  

Hack the Future is an all-day party / hackathon for youth, to show you what its like to be a hacker and see if its for you. We wont tell you what to do. Youll be free to work on whatever you want. Well try to keep you from getting stuck, and well give you a place to start, if you want one. This is a unique opportunity to learn the the state of the art in software engineering from the people who do it for a living.

 

 

Parents, dont reserve a ticket for yourself. Once youve signed the waiver, we encourage you to let your children learn on their own! If you want to stay and join in, youre welcome, but we wont have a T-shirt for you.

Bring a laptop for programming and signed waiver and medical information sheet. The waiver and required medical information sheet are available on hackthefuture.org.

events.name: Helping Hacks: The Goodnik Hackathon

Helping Hacks is a hackathon devoted to building digital capital and technological capacity for New York City’s cause-based organizations. events.name: PubCamp West 2012
events.about:
What is #pubcamp, anyway?

PublicMediaCamp, or PubCamp for short, is a nationwide series of gathering focused on forging greater collaboration between public media organizations and their communities. Inspired by unconferences such as Foocamp and Barcamp, PubCamps are informal opportunities for techies and community media makers to get together with NPR and PBS staff and develop projects together.

Who is in charge of this thing?

#PubCampWest is a collaboration between PBS SoCaL, KQED, KPBS, KPCC and the community.

Is there an agenda?

The loosely styled conference will tackle three topics: TBD

A few weeks prior to the conference, we’ll let you pitch and vote on topic ideas.

Happy Hour
August 24th 6pm-10pm
Meet your fellow PubCampers.

24 Hour PubCamp Hackathon Begins
August 24th 7pm 
Developers start your engines. Use the creative buzz happening at the Happy Hour to fuel one project to hack together during the course of PubCamp. Complete your working prototype in 24 hours and present it to your fellow PubCampers.

PubCamp Sessions
August 25th 10am-5pm 
Earn those camp merit badges for participating in pubcamp sessions throughout the day. Lunch and beverages will be provided. Contact Jasmine Bulin at PBS SoCaL to donate food/drinks or volunteer as a PubCamp Counselor.

Hackathon Ends
August 25th 7pm 

PubCampfire
August 25th 5pm-8pm 
Well wrap up PubCamp with presentations from the sessions, the product/s out of the hackathon, and a special takeaway to keep you motivated after PubCamp ends. Beverages and appetizers will be provided.

Do you have to be part of public media or on the West Coast to come?

Nope. We’re inviting everyone: developers, designers, bloggers, other media types and the general public. If you live outside of California, you’re invited, too. 

Can I help?

Of course! We’d love help. Contact Jasmine Bulin at PBS SoCaL.

Will there be food and drink?

Yes. We’ve got some food and drink coming. But if you would like to contribute food, drink or something else contact Jasmine Bulin at PBS SoCaL.

Will there be Wi-Fi and places for me to plug in?

We’ll have free wi-fi and some places for you to plug in, if need be.

Do I have to RSVP?

Yes. We can only fit so many people!
